instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not booting
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not booting. Spinning fan and orange light. Fan restarts 3 x and then does not boot, i do see the screen is turning on. Checked the SMC and <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. Some pads have discoloring but no real signs of liquid damage. USB Mouse lights up. Pin 8 <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> has 3.42v. No short on the pins of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and resistors measure OK. What more should I check?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not booting
threads.message: If the mouse lights the board is alive. <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> high? <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> going power to LCD?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not booting
threads.message: You can mark as solved replaced some small R near SMC
